page.title: 08FARMING.
page.content: { MODERN HUSBANDRY IN OWSTON { __________________________ Farming in the Owston area varies from traditional to modern methods. Wheat, barley, oilseed-rape,oats and grass are the main crops grown. Grass is cut from permanent pasture and leys to make both silage and hay. After harvest straw is baled: barley for fodder and wheat for bedding. The excess is burned. This is a traditonal {'beef and sheep'}area. All the farms have cattle, two have sheep, one has {40 }dairy cows and another{200 free-range chickens. Beef is produced from such breeds as the Friesian, Hereford, Hereford cross Friesian and Charolais. They are at grass throughout the summer and many are housed during the winter. The sheep are Swale crossed with a Blue_faced Leicester ram.
